package available CRAN, check installed version 1.0.0 . , development version can installed GitHub. install stable version package, users must run:
code: # Install CRAN version (check package version, must be 1.0.0 or above) install.packages("letsRept")  #OR  # Install development version from GitHub # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("joao-svalencar/letsRept")  library(letsRept)

text: NOTE: functions use parallel processing default. Parallel processing may affect system performance. Adjust number cores according needs. snippet showing access number available cores computer provided along functions examples.

Retrieves species information Reptile Database using binomial name. reptSearch() supports synonym-based queries. provided binomial match currently valid species name, function automatically passes query reptAdvancedSearch(synonym = binomial). cases, synonym can unambiguously resolved valid species, function return corresponding species information. Otherwise, provides link (can accessed using reptSpecies(url = link)) list species include queried synonym synonymy.
code: # single species: reptSearch(binomial = "Apostolepis adhara")  # If user wants to check the list of references related to species, as listed in RDB: reptSearch(binomial = "Bothrops pauloensis", getRef=TRUE)

text: Retrieves reference list given species Reptile Database. default, returns citation link reference source (available). user sets getLink = FALSE, function returns plain-text references. function useful extract citation metadata taxonomic historical analyses.
code: # Basic usage reptRefs("Boa constrictor")  # If you want only reference texts, without links: reptRefs("Boa constrictor", getLink = FALSE)

text: Creates link page derived Advanced Search RD (multiple species page): reptAdvancedSearch(synonym = "example") return species information directly (via reptSearch("example")) synonym uniquely matches single valid species. exact = TRUE argument Boa example parses information strictly “Boa”, avoiding return genus like Pseudoboa, Boaedon. ⚠️ Note: argument exact work properly searches using logical arguments (e.g. /). want force exact match (e.g., “Boa” phrase) multiple terms (e.g., “Boa Apostolepis”), must manually include quotes input string, e.g., “"Boa" Apostolepis”.
code: # create multiple species link: link_boa <- reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Boa", exact = TRUE) #returns a link to a list of all Boa species.  link_apo <- reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Apostolepis") #returns a link to a list of all Apostolepis species  link <- reptAdvancedSearch(higher = "snakes", location = "Brazil") #returns a link to a list of all snake species in Brazil  link <- reptAdvancedSearch(year = "2010 OR 2011 OR 2012") #returns a link to a list of all species described from 2010 to 2012

text: Retrieve species data species link created reptAdvancedSearch. User can also copy paste url RD webpage containing list species derived advanced search. includes higher taxa information, authors, year description, species url. default function uses parallel processing, default set use half available cores. user wants use just one core, options backup saving based checkpoint argument. ⚠️ Note: console messages, warnings, progress updates can silenced. However, reptSpecies() issues helpful warning species information fails retrieved, along instructions access entries function output.
code: #check number of available cores: install.packages("parallel") parallel::detectCores()  # sample multiple species data: #Returns higher taxa information and species url: boa <- reptSpecies(link_boa, taxonomicInfo = TRUE, getLink = TRUE) #link from reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Boa")  #example 2 apo <- reptSpecies(link_apo, taxonomicInfo = TRUE, getLink = TRUE) #link from reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Apostolepis")  #Returns only species url - Faster and recommended for large datasets: boa <- reptSpecies(link_boa, taxonomicInfo = FALSE, getLink = TRUE) #link from reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Boa")  #example 2 apo <- reptSpecies(link_apo, taxonomicInfo = FALSE, getLink = TRUE) #link from reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Apostolepis")  #With checkpoint and backups (only without parallel sampling: a lot slower but safer): path <- "path/to/save/backup_file.rds" #not to run just example  apo <- reptSpecies(link_apo, taxonomicInfo = FALSE, getLink = TRUE, checkpoint=6, backup_file=path) #link from reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Apostolepis")

text: function summarizes taxonomic content species list, typically object created reptSpecies() higher taxa information. object provided summarizes internal dataset allReptiles.
code: # summary of internal database allReptiles reptStats()   # filter by family and return summary table (internal database) reptStats(family = "Elapidae") reptStats(family = "Elapidae", verbose = TRUE)  # creating a subset from RDB link <- reptAdvancedSearch(higher="snakes", location = "Brazil") snakes_br <- reptSpecies(link, taxonomicInfo = TRUE)  # summarizing subset reptStats(snakes_br) reptStats(snakes_br, family = "Viperidae", verbose = TRUE)

text: Samples species synonyms either using binomial data frame species names species link (e.g.: result reptSpecies(link, getLink=TRUE)). default function uses parallel processing, default set use half available cores. ⚠️ Note: console messages, warnings, progress updates can silenced. However, reptSynonyms() issues helpful warning species information fails retrieved, along instructions access entries original data frame. complex regex pattern used sample synonyms Reptile Database quite efficient, still samples 0.2% incorrect format. cases represent unusual nomenclature users might face problems trying match current valid names. case, fixed (potentially) unusual synonym formats internal dataset allSynonyms (last update: 23rd May, 2025)
code: #check number of available cores: install.packages("parallel") parallel::detectCores()  # sample species synonyms boa_syn <- reptSynonyms(boa) # using data frame created, with reptSpecies(boa_link, getLink = TRUE) Bconstrictor_syn <- reptSynonyms(x = "Boa constrictor") # using species binomial  #example 2 apo_syn <- reptSynonyms(apo)

text: Compares nomenclature user provided vector species (x) RDB nomenclature. User may provide vector current names sampled RDB reptSpecies(), otherwise names x compared internal dataset allReptiles (dataset documentation see RDB version (current May, 2025). function returns species either unmatched (“review”) matched RDB list, . Species requires nomenclature review usually queried reptSync(), matched species ideally queried reptSplitCheck reference date parsed argument pubDate.
code: my_species <- data.frame(species = c("Boa constrictor", "Pantherophis guttatus", "Fake species"))  reptCompare(my_species) reptCompare(my_species, filter = "review") reptCompare(my_species, filter = "matched")

text: Initially inspired function aswSync package AmphiNom (Liedtke, 2018). recursive function package, using previous functions order provide likely updated nomenclature queried species. default function uses parallel processing, default set use half available cores. function divided two main steps. works: Step 1 function queries vector species (e.g.: IUCN, regional list), check validity reptSearch returns data frame current valid species names. reptSearch finds species page assumes valid name queried species returns status “up_to_date”. reptSearch doesn’t find species parses binomial reptAdvancedSearch using synonym filter. reptAvancedSearch returns link species page species name considered valid synonym queried function returns status "updated". Otherwise, reptAvancedSearch return link page list species, function assumes queried synonym assigned valid names returns status: "ambiguous". queried species return species page page multiple species function returns columns "RDB" "status" sentence "not_found". Step 2 Step 2 activated solveAmbiguity = TRUE. reptAvancedSearch returns link page list species, link parsed reptSpecies collects species names urls automatically parses resulting data frame reptSynonyms. Finally, result reptSynonyms function compares queried species listed synonyms. queried species actually listed synonym one searched species (e.g. queried name synonym, mentioned comments section), function return valid name status "updated". queried species actually synonym one valid species, function return species names status still "ambiguous". column "RDB" shows current valid name according Reptile Database. Pay special attention "status" column: status: "up_to_date" - Species name provided current valid name found Reptile Database "updated" - Species name provided synonym, current valid name reported unambiguously. "ambiguous" - Species name provided considered synonym one current valid species, likely split taxonomy. "not_found" - Species name provided query current valid name synonym according Reptile Database. status derived typo within species name. rare situation status can pop current valid name updated query found list synonyms. "merge" - Multiple names query now considered synonyms single valid species, likely synonymization. ⚠️ ATTENTION!⚠️ letsRept make authoritative taxonomic decisions. matches input names currently accepted names Reptile Database (RDB). name marked "up_to_date" may still refer taxon split, thus may reflect recent population-level taxonomy, see function reptSplitCheck .
code: #check number of available cores: install.packages("parallel") parallel::detectCores()  # comparing synonyms: query <- c("Vieira-Alencar authoristicus",            "Boa atlantica",            "Boa diviniloqua",            "Boa imperator",            "Boa constrictor longicauda")  reptSync(query)  #example 2: query <- c("Vieira-Alencar authorisensis",            "Apostolepis ambiniger",            "Apostolepis cerradoensis",            "Elapomorphus assimilis",            "Apostolepis tertulianobeui",            "Apostolepis goiasensis")  reptSync(query)

text: Species names recent databases likely marked status "up_to_date". However, function reptSync indicates whether queried binomial currently valid. cases, species may undergone taxonomic split, part original populations retains name others described new species. reptSync account cases, recommended review "up_to_date" species potential taxonomic splits. assist , function reptSplitCheck queries binomial names synonyms using reptAdvancedSearch, checks whether associated species described user-defined date (e.g., publication date dataset used). default function uses parallel processing, default set use half available cores. Pay special attention "status" column: status: "up_to_date" – species name provided synonym species described pubDate. "check_split" – species name provided synonym least one valid species described pubDate, suggesting possible taxonomic split. "not_found" - temporary status detect species listed synonyms , appear advanced search (e.g.: correct RDB). OBS: argument includeAll set default (FALSE), queried species synonym species described year pubDate already included queried species list, queried species receive status "up_to_date". check every possible taxonomic split regardless whether new species already present queried species list, change argument value TRUE. Attention: column "RDB" shows current valid names species described , , pubDate according Reptile Database. show queried species, aware reptSplitCheck valid names (e.g.: “matched”, reptCompare). Therefore, "check_split" status highlight users must check data related queried species used (e.g.: species traits) divided (e.g.: distribution) "RDB" column species. words, example , mean Tantilla melanocephala current valid name T. selmae. means users must ensure use queried nomenclature overlook possibility data, part , assigned T. selmae instead.
code: query <- c("Atractus dapsilis",            "Atractus trefauti",            "Atractus snethlageae",            "Tantilla melanocephala",            "Oxybelis aeneus",            "Oxybelis rutherfordi")  reptSplitCheck(query, pubDate = 2019) # pubDate of Nogueira et al., Atlas of Brazilian Snakes reptSplitCheck(query, pubDate = 2019, includeAll = TRUE)

text: function developed exclusively improve visualization reptSync reptSplitCheck outcomes. Queried species many current valid names break data frame visualization R console. reptTidySyn stacks current valid names improves data visualization. Moreover, argument filter, allows users filter printed data frame “status” users can focus status want evaluate.
code: query <- c("Vieira-Alencar authorisensis",            "Apostolepis ambiniger",            "Apostolepis cerradoensis",            "Elapomorphus assimilis",            "Apostolepis tertulianobeui",            "Apostolepis goiasensis")  df <- reptSync(query) reptTidySyn(df)

what: An Interface to the Reptile Database
title: An Interface to the Reptile Database
text: package developed facilitate processes reptile nomenclature update based search species synonyms according Reptile Databse website (Uetz et al., 2025). Currently, package access many species information Reptile Database using R interface. hope useful, people trying match databases different sources (IUCN, species traits database, etc), trying get summaries given higher taxa region (e.g.: Snakes Brazil). can also just print single species information directly R. feedback, suggestion request welcome!

what: Search The Reptile Database website (RDB): Advanced — reptAdvancedSearch
title: Search The Reptile Database website (RDB): Advanced — reptAdvancedSearch
text: Creates search URL retrieving species lists RDB based multiple filters. URL primarily used reptSpecies, can also used manually advanced queries. synonym provided can unambiguously matched valid species, function also prints detailed information species.

title: Search The Reptile Database website (RDB): Advanced — reptAdvancedSearch
code: reptAdvancedSearch(   higher = NULL,   genus = NULL,   year = NULL,   common_name = NULL,   synonym = NULL,   location = NULL,   verbose = TRUE,   exact = FALSE )

title: Search The Reptile Database website (RDB): Advanced — reptAdvancedSearch
text: higher Character string. higher-level reptile taxon genus (e.g., "snakes" "Boidae"). genus Character string. current valid name reptile genus (e.g., "Apostolepis"). year Character string. Filters search year species description (e.g., "2025"). common_name Character string. common name potentially linked species genus (e.g., "tree boa"). synonym Character string. name potentially regarded synonym valid taxon (e.g., "Boa diviniloqua"). location Character string. country region name used list species expected occur . verbose Logical. passed reptSpecies() case provided synonym corresponds unambiguously valid species. TRUE, prints status messages species information console. Default TRUE. exact Logical. return outputs matches exactly searched term (e.g., avoid returning genus "Boaedon" searching "Boa"). Default FALSE.

title: Search The Reptile Database website (RDB): Advanced — reptAdvancedSearch
text: character string containing URL used reptSpecies. provided synonym corresponds unambiguously valid species, function also prints species information retrieved RDB console.

title: Search The Reptile Database website (RDB): Advanced — reptAdvancedSearch
text: argument exact work properly searches using logical arguments (e.g. /). want force exact match (e.g., "Boa" phrase) multiple terms (e.g., "Boa Apostolepis"), must manually include quotes input string, e.g., "\"Boa\" Apostolepis". Logical operators (e.g., , ) supported properly formatted search. exclude terms, use leading minus sign (e.g., higher = "-snakes") following RDB's query syntax, instead using . synonym matched single valid species, function also display species' full information side effect.

title: Search The Reptile Database website (RDB): Advanced — reptAdvancedSearch
code: # \donttest{ reptAdvancedSearch(higher = "snakes", year = "2010", location = "Brazil") #> Species found: 7 #> Proceed to reptSpecies() with the returned link #> [1] "https://reptile-database.reptarium.cz/advanced_search?taxon=snakes&year=2010&location=Brazil&submit=Search" reptAdvancedSearch(year = "2010 OR 2011 OR 2012") #> Species found: 431 #> Proceed to reptSpecies() with the returned link #> [1] "https://reptile-database.reptarium.cz/advanced_search?year=2010+OR+2011+OR+2012&submit=Search" reptAdvancedSearch(genus = "Apostolepis OR \"Boa\" OR Atractus") #quotes "Boa" #> Species found: 193 #> Proceed to reptSpecies() with the returned link #> [1] "https://reptile-database.reptarium.cz/advanced_search?genus=Apostolepis+OR+%22Boa%22+OR+Atractus&submit=Search" # }

what: Compare a Species nomenclature with Reptile Database Data — reptCompare
title: Compare a Species nomenclature with Reptile Database Data — reptCompare
text: function compares list species (x) another list (y), typically Reptile Database (RDB). y provided, defaults using internal object allReptiles. function returns species either unmatched ("review") matched RDB list, .

title: Compare a Species nomenclature with Reptile Database Data — reptCompare
code: reptCompare(x = NULL, y = NULL, filter = NULL)

title: Compare a Species nomenclature with Reptile Database Data — reptCompare
text: x character vector data frame containing column named species species names compared. y Optional. character vector data frame containing column named species compare . Defaults internal object allReptiles. filter Optional. character string. "review", returns unmatched species. "matched", returns matched species. NULL (default), returns data frame .

title: Compare a Species nomenclature with Reptile Database Data — reptCompare
text: character vector (filter "review" "matched"), data frame columns: species Species names x status Comparison result: "review" "matched"

title: Compare a Species nomenclature with Reptile Database Data — reptCompare
code: my_species <- data.frame(species = c("Boa constrictor", "Pantherophis guttatus", "Fake species")) reptCompare(my_species) #> No RDB list provided, comparing with internal data 'allReptiles' #> Error in data.frame(species = absent, status = "absent"): arguments imply differing number of rows: 0, 1 reptCompare(my_species, filter = "review") #> No RDB list provided, comparing with internal data 'allReptiles' #> [1] "Fake species" reptCompare(my_species, filter = "matched") #> No RDB list provided, comparing with internal data 'allReptiles' #> [1] "Boa constrictor"       "Pantherophis guttatus"

[atlantica]  #>  - Holotype: unlocated fide McDiarmid et al., 1999, Reynolds & Henderson 2018) [occidentalis]  #>  #> Diagnosis: #>  - Diagnosis (constrictor in Honduras): “Boa constrictor differs from all other Honduran snakes by the combination of having enlarged ventral scales that do not extend the entire width of the venter, no enlarged scales on the top of the head, mostly entire subcaudal scales, smooth dorsal scales in more than 60 rows at midbody, a huge adult size, and in lacking labial pits.” (McCranie 2011: 61)  #>  - Unfortunately we had to temporarily remove additional information as this was scraped by multiple AI companies who sell that data to their customers. These details, e.g. detailed descriptions or comparisons (about 3414 characters) are available for collaborators and contributors. Please contact us for details.  #>  #> Comment: #>  - Synonymy: Boa constrictor melanogaster Langhammer 1983 is a nomen dubium fide Price & Russo 1991. It’s type locality is “Ecuador, Morona-Santiago, nr. Río Yaupi Catholic Mission, upstream from Ró Santiago, Jivaro Indians, Holotype: UMMZ. Synonymy partly after STIMSON 1969. We follow Reynolds (2025) in recognizing B. atlantica as a synonym or subspecies of B. constrictor, given the poor documentation and justification in Gonzalez et al. 2024.  #>  - Subspecies: Hynková et al. (2010) and others suggested that B. c. imperator may be a full species. If so, they also suggested that it would comprise all populations of the Central American clade, including B. c. sabogae and B. c. longicauda. Hynkova et al. found no molecular support for the distinction between the nominotypic subspecies and B. c. amarali. Hynkova et al. did not analyze all (sub-) species, e.g. orophias or nebulosa. If B. atlantica is treated as species, B. occidentalis needs to be treated as species too. However, both could be treated as subspecies of B. constrictor too. See phylogeny in Gonzalez et al. 2024.  #>  - Crother et al. (2009) have found a snake shed in Manitoba, Canada, which was identified by DNA sequencing as most likely coming from Boa constrictor.  #>  - Genome: The Boa constrictor genome has been sequenced by Vicoso et al. (2013).  #>  - Distribution: B. c. constrictor s.l. only occurs in South America; all other reports from Central America and the Caribbean represent subspecies (now other species). Hence not anymore in Mexico (Tamaulipas, Quéretaro, Veracruz, Puebla, Jalisco, Hidalgo), Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama. Not in Yucatan state (Mexico), fide Gonzalez-Sanchez et al. 2017. See maps in Bonny 2007. Distribution: Not listed for San Luis Potosí by Lemos-Espinal et al. 2018 (checklist SLP). Not in Morelos fide Lemos-Espinal 2020 (where it is replaced by B. sigma). See also map in Nogueira et al. 2019 for South America. See map in Gonzalez et al. 2024 for map of B. atlantica.  #>  - Relative abundance in Honduras: rare  #>  - Type species: Boa constrictor LINNAEUS 1758: 215 is the type species of the genus Boa LINNAEUS 1758: 214.  #>  - Type genus. Boa Linnaeus 1758 is the type genus of the family Boidae (sensu Pyron et al. 2014). The famly (sensu Pyron et al. 2014) contains the following genera: Boa, Chilabothrus, Corallus, Epicrates, Eunectes.  #>  - Karyotypes: Viana et al. 2020 present karyotypes for Boa constrictor and other boids.  #>  - Habitat: partly arboreal (Harrington et al. 2018).  #>  - Extinct species (genus Boa): B. blanchardensis Bochaton & Bailon 2018  #>  - Chresonymy (atlantica): after Gonzalez et al. 2024, see there also for references.  #>  - NCBI taxonID: 499170 [occidentalis]  #>  #> Etymology: #>  - Named after the Latin word constrictus, meaning "to constrict or contract."  #>  - B. c. atlantica was named after the Atlantic coast but mainly the Atlantic Forest ecoregion, the homeland of several endemic species, including this new Boa.  #>  - B. c. longicauda was apparently named after its long tail, from Latin cauda = tail.  #>  - B. c. ortonii was named after Named after Prof. James Orton, of Williams College, who collected the types during his expedition to Peru in 1876-1877.  #>  - B. c. occidentalis (Latin) refers to the western distribution of this species.  #>  - The genus was named after the Latin word boa, meaning "large [water] snake." Linnaeus obviously did not know whether this species lived in water or not.  However, Fretey 2019 stated that it stems from Latin bos, ‘cow’; ‘kind of snake’ because it feeds first by sucking cows according to Pliny the elder (Liber 8.14).  #>  reptSearch("Boa constrictor", getRef = TRUE) #> Species: #>  - [atlantica]  #>  - Holotype: unlocated fide McDiarmid et al., 1999, Reynolds & Henderson 2018) [occidentalis]  #>  #> Diagnosis: #>  - Diagnosis (constrictor in Honduras): “Boa constrictor differs from all other Honduran snakes by the combination of having enlarged ventral scales that do not extend the entire width of the venter, no enlarged scales on the top of the head, mostly entire subcaudal scales, smooth dorsal scales in more than 60 rows at midbody, a huge adult size, and in lacking labial pits.” (McCranie 2011: 61)  #>  - Unfortunately we had to temporarily remove additional information as this was scraped by multiple AI companies who sell that data to their customers. These details, e.g. detailed descriptions or comparisons (about 3414 characters) are available for collaborators and contributors. Please contact us for details.  #>  #> Comment: #>  - Synonymy: Boa constrictor melanogaster Langhammer 1983 is a nomen dubium fide Price & Russo 1991. It’s type locality is “Ecuador, Morona-Santiago, nr. Río Yaupi Catholic Mission, upstream from Ró Santiago, Jivaro Indians, Holotype: UMMZ. Synonymy partly after STIMSON 1969. We follow Reynolds (2025) in recognizing B. atlantica as a synonym or subspecies of B. constrictor, given the poor documentation and justification in Gonzalez et al. 2024.  #>  - Subspecies: Hynková et al. (2010) and others suggested that B. c. imperator may be a full species. If so, they also suggested that it would comprise all populations of the Central American clade, including B. c. sabogae and B. c. longicauda. Hynkova et al. found no molecular support for the distinction between the nominotypic subspecies and B. c. amarali. Hynkova et al. did not analyze all (sub-) species, e.g. orophias or nebulosa. If B. atlantica is treated as species, B. occidentalis needs to be treated as species too. However, both could be treated as subspecies of B. constrictor too. See phylogeny in Gonzalez et al. 2024.  #>  - Crother et al. (2009) have found a snake shed in Manitoba, Canada, which was identified by DNA sequencing as most likely coming from Boa constrictor.  #>  - Genome: The Boa constrictor genome has been sequenced by Vicoso et al. (2013).  #>  - Distribution: B. c. constrictor s.l. only occurs in South America; all other reports from Central America and the Caribbean represent subspecies (now other species). Hence not anymore in Mexico (Tamaulipas, Quéretaro, Veracruz, Puebla, Jalisco, Hidalgo), Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama. Not in Yucatan state (Mexico), fide Gonzalez-Sanchez et al. 2017. See maps in Bonny 2007. Distribution: Not listed for San Luis Potosí by Lemos-Espinal et al. 2018 (checklist SLP). Not in Morelos fide Lemos-Espinal 2020 (where it is replaced by B. sigma). See also map in Nogueira et al. 2019 for South America. See map in Gonzalez et al. 2024 for map of B. atlantica.  #>  - Relative abundance in Honduras: rare  #>  - Type species: Boa constrictor LINNAEUS 1758: 215 is the type species of the genus Boa LINNAEUS 1758: 214.  #>  - Type genus. Boa Linnaeus 1758 is the type genus of the family Boidae (sensu Pyron et al. 2014). The famly (sensu Pyron et al. 2014) contains the following genera: Boa, Chilabothrus, Corallus, Epicrates, Eunectes.  #>  - Karyotypes: Viana et al. 2020 present karyotypes for Boa constrictor and other boids.  #>  - Habitat: partly arboreal (Harrington et al. 2018).  #>  - Extinct species (genus Boa): B. blanchardensis Bochaton & Bailon 2018  #>  - Chresonymy (atlantica): after Gonzalez et al. 2024, see there also for references.  #>  - NCBI taxonID: 499170 [occidentalis]  #>  #> Etymology: #>  - Named after the Latin word constrictus, meaning "to constrict or contract."  #>  - B. c. atlantica was named after the Atlantic coast but mainly the Atlantic Forest ecoregion, the homeland of several endemic species, including this new Boa.  #>  - B. c. longicauda was apparently named after its long tail, from Latin cauda = tail.  #>  - B. c. ortonii was named after Named after Prof. James Orton, of Williams College, who collected the types during his expedition to Peru in 1876-1877.  #>  - B. c. occidentalis (Latin) refers to the western distribution of this species.  #>  - The genus was named after the Latin word boa, meaning "large [water] snake." Linnaeus obviously did not know whether this species lived in water or not.  However, Fretey 2019 stated that it stems from Latin bos, ‘cow’; ‘kind of snake’ because it feeds first by sucking cows according to Pliny the elder (Liber 8.14).  #>  #> References: #>  - Abalos, J.W., Baez, E.C., & Nader, R. 1964. what: Retrieve Reptile Species and Taxonomic Information from RDB — reptSpecies
title: Retrieve Reptile Species and Taxonomic Information from RDB — reptSpecies
text: Retrieves list reptile species Reptile Database (RDB) based search URL, optionally returns detailed taxonomic information species. function can also save progress disk sampling extract species-specific URLs use.

title: Retrieve Reptile Species and Taxonomic Information from RDB — reptSpecies
code: reptSpecies(   url = NULL,   showProgress = TRUE,   dataList = NULL,   taxonomicInfo = FALSE,   fullHigher = FALSE,   getLink = FALSE,   cores = max(1L, floor(parallel::detectCores()/2)),   checkpoint = NULL,   backup_file = NULL )

title: Retrieve Reptile Species and Taxonomic Information from RDB — reptSpecies
text: url Character string. search URL generated via advanced search RDB website reptAdvancedSearch. showProgress Logical. TRUE, prints sampling progress console. Default FALSE. dataList Optional. data frame columns species url, used extract taxonomic information previously sampled species links. taxonomicInfo Logical. TRUE, returns taxonomic information species, including order, suborder, family, genus, author, year. Default FALSE. fullHigher Logical. TRUE, includes full higher taxonomic hierarchy reported RDB (e.g., including subfamilies). Requires taxonomicInfo = TRUE. Default FALSE. getLink Logical. TRUE, includes RDB URL species (useful follow-functions like reptSynonyms). Default FALSE. cores Integer. Number CPU cores use parallel processing. Default half available cores (min = 1). checkpoint Optional. Integer specifying number species process saving temporary backup. Backup saved cores = 1. set 1, saves progress species (safest slowest). backup_file Optional. Character string specifying path .rds file saving intermediate results checkpoint set. Must end .rds.

title: Retrieve Reptile Species and Taxonomic Information from RDB — reptSpecies
text: taxonomicInfo = FALSE (default), returns character vector species names. taxonomicInfo = TRUE, returns data frame columns: order, suborder (available), family, genus, species, author, year. fullHigher = TRUE, includes additional column full higher taxa classification. getLink = TRUE, includes column URL species’ page RDB.

title: Retrieve Reptile Species and Taxonomic Information from RDB — reptSpecies
text: checkpoint used, progress saved cores = 1. prevents potential write conflicts parallel mode.

title: Retrieve Reptile Species and Taxonomic Information from RDB — reptSpecies

what: Check for potential taxonomic splits in a query — reptSplitCheck
title: Check for potential taxonomic splits in a query — reptSplitCheck
text: Check potential taxonomic splits query

title: Check for potential taxonomic splits in a query — reptSplitCheck
code: reptSplitCheck(   x,   pubDate = NULL,   includeAll = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   cores = max(1L, floor(parallel::detectCores()/2)),   showProgress = TRUE )

title: Check for potential taxonomic splits in a query — reptSplitCheck
text: x character vector species names check. Usually database. pubDate Integer. year (e.g., 2019) used reference date check potential taxonomic split includeAll Logical; TRUE, include species described since pubDate regardless already included queried species list. Default FALSE verbose Logical; TRUE, prints progress messages. Default TRUE. cores Integer. Number CPU cores use parallel processing. Default half available cores (min = 1). showProgress Logical. TRUE, prints data sampling progress. Default TRUE.

title: Check for potential taxonomic splits in a query — reptSplitCheck
text: data frame following columns: query: original input names. RDB: best-matching valid names according Reptile Database. status: status label indicating result match ("up_to_date", "updated", "ambiguous", "not_found").

title: Check for potential taxonomic splits in a query — reptSplitCheck
code: query <- c( "Atractus dapsilis", "Atractus trefauti", "Atractus snethlageae", "Tantilla melanocephala", "Oxybelis aeneus", "Oxybelis rutherfordi", "Vieira-Alencar authoristicus", "Oxybelis aeneus", "Bothrops pauloensis")  # \donttest{ result <- reptSplitCheck(x=query,                         pubDate = 2019,                         cores = 2,                         showProgress = FALSE)  result <- reptSplitCheck(x=query,                         pubDate = 2019,                         cores = 2,                         showProgress = FALSE,                         includeAll = TRUE) # }

title: Summarize Taxonomic Composition — reptStats
text: function summarizes taxonomic content species list, typically object created reptSpecies higher taxa information. object provided summarizes internal dataset allReptiles.

title: Summarize Taxonomic Composition — reptStats
code: reptStats(   x = letsRept::allReptiles,   verbose = FALSE,   order = NULL,   suborder = NULL,   family = NULL,   genus = NULL )

title: Summarize Taxonomic Composition — reptStats
text: x data frame containing reptile taxonomy data. Defaults internal dataset letsRept::allReptiles. verbose Logical. TRUE, returns list taxon names rank. FALSE (default), returns summary table counts. order Optional. character string specifying taxonomic order filter (e.g., "Squamata"). suborder Optional. character string specifying taxonomic suborder filter (e.g., "Serpentes"). family Optional. character string specifying family filter (e.g., "Elapidae"). genus Optional. character string specifying genus filter (e.g., "Micrurus").

title: Summarize Taxonomic Composition — reptStats
text: Either named list taxonomic units (verbose = TRUE) data frame taxonomic ranks number units per rank (verbose = FALSE).

title: Summarize Taxonomic Composition — reptStats
text: output can either compact table taxonomic unit counts verbose list names within rank. Optional arguments allow user filter dataset specific taxonomic levels (e.g., order, suborder, family, genus) summarizing.

what: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
title: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
text: Queries list species names reptSearch() returns data frame currently valid names taxonomic status input.

title: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
code: reptSync(   x,   solveAmbiguity = TRUE,   cores = max(1L, floor(parallel::detectCores()/2)),   showProgress = TRUE,   getLink = FALSE )

title: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
text: x character vector taxon names matched (e.g., species lists, phylogenetic tip labels, trait table entries). solveAmbiguity Logical. TRUE, attempts resolve ambiguous names retrieving possible valid species query may refer. Default TRUE. cores Integer. Number CPU cores use parallel processing. Default half available cores (min = 1). showProgress Logical. TRUE, displays progress updates processing. Default TRUE. getLink Logical. TRUE, retrieves searched species URLs. Defaults FALSE.

title: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
text: data frame following columns: query: original input names. RDB: best-matching valid names according Reptile Database. status: status label indicating result match ("up_to_date", "updated", "ambiguous", "not_found"). url: Optional, getLink = TRUE returns URL species page retrieved match, list possible matches ambiguous.

title: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
text: reptSync() make authoritative taxonomic decisions. matches input names currently accepted names Reptile Database (RDB). name marked "up_to_date" may still refer taxon split, thus may reflect recent population-level taxonomy. ambiguous names, url field may contain multiple links corresponding valid species queried name considered synonym. See package vignettes details.

title: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
text: Liedtke, H. C. (2018). AmphiNom: amphibian systematics tool. Systematics Biodiversity, 17(1), 1–6. https://doi.org/10.1080/14772000.2018.1518935

title: Synchronize Species Names Using The Reptile Database — reptSync
code: query <- c("Vieira-Alencar authoristicus", "Boa atlantica", "Boa diviniloqua", "Boa imperator")  # \donttest{ reptSync(x = query, cores = 2) #> Sampling synonyms to approach ambiguity for 1 species #>                          query                           RDB     status #> 1 Vieira-Alencar authoristicus                     not_found  not_found #> 2                Boa atlantica               Boa constrictor    updated #> 3              Boa diviniloqua Boa constrictor; Boa orophias  ambiguous #> 4                Boa imperator                 Boa imperator up_to_date # }

what: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
title: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
text: Retrieves data frame containing current valid names reptile species along recognized synonyms, listed Reptile Database (RDB). Optionally, references citing synonym can also included.

title: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
code: reptSynonyms(   x,   getRef = FALSE,   showProgress = TRUE,   checkpoint = NULL,   backup_file = NULL,   resume = FALSE,   cores = max(1L, floor(parallel::detectCores()/2)) )

title: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
text: x character string species binomial data frame columns species url, typically output reptSpecies getLink = TRUE. getRef Logical. TRUE, includes reference(s) synonym mentioned. Default FALSE. showProgress Logical. TRUE, prints data sampling progress. Default TRUE. checkpoint Optional. Integer specifying number species process saving temporary backup. Backup saved cores = 1. set 1, saves progress species (safest slowest). backup_file Optional. Character string specifying path .rds file used save resume intermediate results. Required using checkpoint resume. resume Logical. TRUE, resumes sampling previous run using file provided backup_file. works cores = 1. cores Integer. Number CPU cores use parallel processing. Default half available cores (min = 1).

title: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
text: data frame columns: species: valid species name according RDB. synonym: recognized synonym species. reference (optional): getRef = TRUE, citation synonym reported.

title: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
text: enable safe resuming backup progress saving, set cores = 1. Parallel processing support backups.

title: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
text: Uetz, P., Freed, P., Aguilar, R., Reyes, F., Kudera, J., & Hošek, J. (eds.) (2025). Reptile Database. Retrieved http://www.reptile-database.org Liedtke, H. C. (2018). AmphiNom: amphibian systematics tool. Systematics Biodiversity, 17(1), 1–6. doi:10.1080/14772000.2018.1518935

title: Retrieve Synonyms for Reptile Species from RDB — reptSynonyms
code: # Filter species belonging to genus Boa boa <- letsRept::allReptiles[grep("^Boa\\s", letsRept::allReptiles$species), ]  # \donttest{ # Retrieve synonyms (without references) boa_syn <- reptSynonyms(boa, getRef = FALSE, cores = 2) #>  #> Synonyms sampling complete! Bconstrictor_syn <- reptSynonyms(x = "Boa constrictor") #>  #> Synonyms sampling complete! # }

what: Printing reptSync and reptSplitCheck outcomes in a tidy way — reptTidySyn
title: Printing reptSync and reptSplitCheck outcomes in a tidy way — reptTidySyn
text: Prints data frame derived reptSync reptSplitCheck tidy way. Optionally, filters data frame species unresolved nomenclature .

title: Printing reptSync and reptSplitCheck outcomes in a tidy way — reptTidySyn
code: reptTidySyn(df, filter = NULL)

title: Printing reptSync and reptSplitCheck outcomes in a tidy way — reptTidySyn
text: df data frame derivated reptSync filter Logical. TRUE print species entries unresolved nomenclature (e.g.: ambiguous not_found). Default TRUE

title: Printing reptSync and reptSplitCheck outcomes in a tidy way — reptTidySyn
text: Invisibly returns NULL. Used side-effect printing .

title: Printing reptSync and reptSplitCheck outcomes in a tidy way — reptTidySyn
code: df <- data.frame(   species = c("Genus epithet 1",                "Genus epithet 2",               "Genus epithet 3",               "Genus epithet 4",               "Genus epithet 5"),   synonyms = c("Genus epithet 1.1; Genus epithet 1.2",                 "Genus epithet 2",                 "Genus epithet 3",                 "Not found",                 "Genus epithet 5.1; Genus epithet 5.2; Genus epithet 5.3"),   status = c("ambiguous",               "updated",              "up_to_date",              "not_found",              "ambiguous"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE ) reptTidySyn(df, filter = c("ambiguous", "not_found")) #> species           synonyms            status     #> -----------------------------------------------  #> Genus epithet 1   Genus epithet 1.1   ambiguous  #>                   Genus epithet 1.2              #> Genus epithet 4   Not found           not_found  #> Genus epithet 5   Genus epithet 5.1   ambiguous  #>                   Genus epithet 5.2              #>                   Genus epithet 5.3
